messages.subject: RE: [unschoolingbasics] swimming (was: losing friends)
messages.msgSnippet: i havnt taught my kids to swim.  in arizona where everyone takes lessons i put my 18m old in lessons and he hated them so i descided he would learn when ready.
messages.messageBody:
i havnt taught my kids to swim. in arizona where everyone takes lessons i
put my 18m old in lessons and he hated them so i descided he would learn
when ready. this past summer just before he turned 5 he put his head in the
water. a few weeks later he was floating on his back. he can swim under
water now but not ontop. my almost 4 year old follows behind his brother by
a couple weeks on each thing he does. people keep asking me if i am going
to do lessons but honestly they are happy going at their own pace and we go
swimming alot.

messages.subject: swimming (was: losing friends)
messages.msgSnippet: Adriana wrote: PS please don t scold me for being a bad mom and not teaching them to swim - I PROMISE they just weren t ready yet and I was always ULTRA ULTRA
messages.messageBody:
Adriana wrote:


PS please don't scold me for being a bad mom and not
teaching them to swim -


I PROMISE they just weren't ready yet and I was always ULTRA
ULTRA careful


around water (still am, but at least I don't have to act
paranoid about it


anymore!)





Alice
writes:


It�s my understanding that drowning accidents happen more to
swimmers than non-swimmers. Swimmers think they can handle themselves around
water, don�t always take the precautions that non-swimmers do, and find
themselves in dangerous situations they can�t always extricate themselves from.





Gramma Alice


Breastfeeding is the biological norm for infants. It is a relationship that provides food, connection, protection from illness to the baby and stress reducing hormones to the mother.
